description.narrative:
1. Political update 2017 Zimbabwe’s political, economic and social environment is increasingly fragile. Zimbabwe’s problems – economic, political, social, policy and infrastructural - are well documented. The country is currently facing a debilitating liquidity crisis which has led to the government’s inability to pay civil servants on time prompting protests which have been violently crushed by the state. Government is struggling to pay civil servants resulting in frequent changes to pay dates while industry is currently operating at below 30% of its capacity. The threat of the government introducing government bond notes as a surrogate currency is causing a run on the banks and both business and public is converting as much credit into cash as possible.
There is no consensus on how to resolve the socio-economic and political problems facing the country. This situation is further exacerbated by the lack of cohesion in developing national responses aimed at economic recovery and building lasting peace. While the government and ruling party ZANU PF struggles to meet its election promises, opposition parties and civil society have been debilitated by the result of the elections, they are currently fragmented and not able to coalesce as the watchdog of political actors; this makes the role of Parliament as the house that represents national constituencies ever more important.
2. Programme & Theory of Change Update The SP programme is divided into three parts: a programme focussed on the Zimbabwe parliament together by ZI, AWEPA and NIMD The Zimbabwe Political Parties Dialogue (ZPPD) programme implemented by ZI and co-funded by NIMD, DIPD and the EU (EU funding to be secured). An ILA component of the programme together with the Zimbabwe Europe Network. This programme feeds into the results framework of the NIMD/AWEPA International Lobby and Advocacy (ILA) agenda. 2017 will be the start-up of the € 500.000 per year ZPPD programme funded by the EU. This programme will fit in the current ToC for the programme but will need an updated results framework to capture the results for the entire programme.
Also the decision is made to focus more on ILA due to the big role the EU can play in creating space for civil society to operate in Zimbabwe. This programme will be developed jointly with ZEN.

Political actors are defined as the combined main target group of the Strategic Partnership: - (representatives of) political parties - politicians - (Members of) Parliament and its Committees - Other elected representatives at local levels. NIMD will primarily focus on political parties.

mailing-address.narrative: NIMD, Passage 31, 2511 AB The Hague, The Netherlands
